text: [MUSIC PLAYING]

It was not an easy
decision for my parents
to bring me into this world.

Back in 1980s, my parents
would be severely punished

for breaching China's
one-child policy.

And the decision to have a girl,
despite already having a son,
was unimaginable.

Because most people would
give up on a girl just
to wait for a boy.

Even though it
cost my mom her job

and my dad was removed
from his position,
they decided to have me.

"Let's call her Jiao,"
my relative suggested.

A Chinese character
that would imbue me

was the traditional feminine
traits of tenderness
and submissiveness.

But my parents saw
more than that in me.

They gave me another
character, Jun,

which means a strong
person with virtue

who dares to become the
master of her own fate.

And that character
became my guide.

One year ago, I had a
stable job in a city

I loved, living the dream
I was taught to dream.

But as my parents saw
more than that in me,
I saw more in the world.

And here at HBS I've grown
more empowered to forge

my own convictions
and live accordingly.

I draw strength from my parents,
my heritage, and my name.

I want to inspire others
to do that as well.
